No, both base them on feelings and interpretations of their own experiences.

 
 Not all interpretations are equal, however. 
 
 We each construct a model of the world around us by interacting with it and getting feedback. What we call 'material' or 'real' or 'true' is just another way of describing meaningful feedback: information that constrains our model.
 
 Some models cannot be constrained because they make no falsifiable predictions; it's impossible for 'reality' to disagree with them. This category of models is what - in recent times - we mean when we say 'supernatural'.
 
 I say in recent times because personal models of god and other supernatural entities have not always been unfalsifiable. If you were to take the scientific method back in time and explain it to early believers they would say that of course god's existence could be scientifically verified; of course prayer would have a statistically measurable effect; of course radiometry would confirm the biblical age of the earth - and so forth. Methodological naturalism only came to be perceived as a threat to theism when those expectations turned out to be unfounded. Subsequently theism has converged upon the relatively modern 'non-overlapping magisteria' model, in which it is impossible for any observation to disprove the existence of god.
 
 The upshot is that taking the existence of such a god as axiomatic is not the same as not taking his existence as axiomatic. The former involves choosing to believe something contrived under duress to be undisprovable.
